normalised: As of Q three two thousand and twenty four, several payment options are prevalent for e-commerce transactions in India. Credit and debit cards, including V-I-S-A, Mastercard, and RuPay, are widely accepted. Many e-commerce platforms also support U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) transactions, allowing users to make payments directly from their bank accounts using apps like Google Pay, PhonePe, and Paytm. These methods generally offer cashback offers if you pay above rupee five hundred.

unnormalised: Digital wallets such as Paytm Wallet, Amazon Pay, and PhonePe Wallet are another common option. These wallets often provide additional security layers and may offer exclusive deals or discounts. Net banking, although sometimes perceived as less convenient than other methods, remains a viable option for those who prefer to use their bank accounts directly. Many e-commerce sites also offer EMI (Equated Monthly Installment) options on purchases above Rs. 10000, facilitated through partnerships with various banks and financial institutions.

unnormalised: Finally, some platforms offer a "cash on delivery" (COD) option, where customers pay for their purchases in cash upon delivery. While COD offers convenience for those without access to digital payment methods, it may incur additional charges and is not always available for all products or locations. It's worth noting that processing fees may apply to transactions exceeding $20.
